explanation:
The correct calculation substitutes \( n = 1 \) into \( 2 - 7n \):  
\( 2 - 7(1) = -5 \).  

The student likely computed \( -7 \times 1 = -7 \), omitting the constant term \( 2 \).  

The error stems from misinterpreting the formula as solely dependent on the coefficient of \( n \), neglecting the additive constant. This aligns with treating the coefficient of \( n \) as the standalone term value, bypassing the full expression.  

This misconception directly caused the error: the student isolated the \( -7n \) component, assumed \( n=1 \), and ignored the \( +2 \).  

It differs from "mixing term and position" (which would involve incorrect \( n \)-values) or "using the first term as the coefficient" (which would imply \( 2 \) is misinterpreted, not omitted).  

The flaw is strictly about disregarding the constant term in the linear expression when calculating the first term.
